update.description:
# Segway Modular API Updates

## Introduction of Steps

This introduces a new API which divides the three Segway tasks, train, identify, and posterior, into steps allowing us to stop the processes at defined intervals to view and potentially modify the input files generated by Segway before and during training. The steps that have been defined are:

* init: Generates all input files, but does not submit any jobs to GMTK \(besides triangulate\). At the end of this step the input.master, segway.str, auxillary files, tri files, and the window.bed will all be generated.
* run: Submits jobs to GMTK. Produces params and viterbi files.
* finish: Selects the best training and identify instances and uses these to generate the output files.
* train-run-round: This step is specific to training. It will run a single round of training and then stop, allowing a user to view results and modify files.

## User Interface Changes

Users wishing to run all steps of a task together may continue to do so the same way they do now, writing segway <task>. 

To run a single step, use the command segway <task>-<step>. For example, segway identify-run will run the identify associated programs. 

A change to all users will be the order of the positional arguments and additional arguments provided to segway. Now users will only be able to specify arguments specific to each task, rather than having a downstream error occur. This means that the commands must now follow the order:

`"segway [GLOBAL_OPTION] TASK [TASK_OPTION] GENOMEDATA [GENOMEDATA ...] TRAINDIR [IDENTIFYDIR]"`

Where global options are those that apply to all tasks such as cluster arguments. Task options are those that are specific to the desired task.
update.title: Split Segway Tasks into Steps

content.raw:
It is true that selected will always be True when subtask is defined, it can occur that selected=True when subtask is also not defined. 

```
            task = task.split(SUB_TASK_DELIMITER)
            task_name = task[0]
            if task_name == "annotate":
                task_name = "identify"

            subtask = task[1:]
```

Here where subtask is defined, it is everything after the SUB\_TASK\_DELIMITER. In the case when something like segway train is called, then subtask=None. In this case, we set every subtask to true.
content.html:
It is true that selected will always be True when subtask is defined, it can occur that selected=True when subtask is also not defined. 

            task = task.split(SUB_TASK_DELIMITER)
            task_name = task[0]
            if task_name == "annotate":
                task_name = "identify"

            subtask = task[1:]

Here where subtask is defined, it is everything after the SUB_TASK_DELIMITER. In the case when something like segway train is called, then subtask=None. In this case, we set every subtask to true.

content.raw: I believe this was mentioned before, but this constructor is only called with two conditions, `(True, subtask)` and `(False)`. Maybe you should just have it so if subtask is defined, it presumed that `selected` is `True` and `False` otherwise. I could be convinced that this code should stay, but currently I'm having trouble coming up for a reason why subtask would be specified and also `False` for selected.
content.html: I believe this was mentioned before, but this constructor is only called with two conditions, (True, subtask) and (False). Maybe you should just have it so if subtask is defined, it presumed that selected is True and False otherwise. I could be convinced that this code should stay, but currently I'm having trouble coming up for a reason why subtask would be specified and also False for selected.

update.description:
# Segway Modular API Updates

## Introduction of Steps

This introduces a new API which divides the three Segway tasks, train, identify, and posterior, into steps allowing us to stop the processes at defined intervals to view and potentially modify the input files generated by Segway before and during training. The steps that have been defined are:

* init: Generates all input files, but does not submit any jobs to GMTK \(besides triangulate\). At the end of this step the input.master, segway.str, auxillary files, tri files, and the window.bed will all be generated.
* run: Submits jobs to GMTK. Produces params and viterbi files.
* finish: Selects the best training and identify instances and uses these to generate the output files.
* train-run-round: This step is specific to training. It will run a single round of training and then stop, allowing a user to view results and modify files.

## User Interface Changes

Users wishing to run all steps of a task together may continue to do so the same way they do now, writing segway <task>. 

To run a single step, use the command segway <task>-<step>. For example, segway identify-run will run the identify associated programs. 

A change to all users will be the order of the positional arguments and additional arguments provided to segway. Now users will only be able to specify arguments specific to each task, rather than having a downstream error occur. This means that the commands must now follow the order:

Where global options are those that apply to all tasks such as cluster arguments. Task options are those that are specific to the desired task.

update.description:
# Segway Modular API Updates

## Introduction of Steps

This introduces a new API which divides the three Segway tasks, train, identify, and posterior, into steps allowing us to stop the processes at defined intervals to view and potentially modify the input files generated by Segway before and during training. The steps that have been defined are:

* init: Generates all input files, but does not submit any jobs to GMTK \(besides triangulate\). At the end of this step the input.master, segway.str, auxillary files, tri files, and the window.bed will all be generated.

* finish: Selects the best training and identify instances and uses these to generate the output files.
* train-run-round: This step is specific to training. It will run a single round of training and then stop, allowing a user to view results and modify files.

## User Interface Changes

Users wishing to run all steps of a task together may continue to do so the same way they do now, writing segway <task>.

content.raw:
apparently you can just use `job_log_file.tell()` \(works without io.open\)

```python
>>> f = open("test.txt", 'a')
>>> f.tell()
0
```
content.html:
apparently you can just use job_log_file.tell() (works without io.open)

>>> f = open("test.txt", 'a')
>>> f.tell()
0

content.raw: Will use seek
content.html: Will use seek

content.raw: filename.exists\(\) won’t work, since the filename will always exist once it is opened in the line above, and this change was made to avoid having to create a flag before opening and having the race condition.
content.html: filename.exists() won’t work, since the filename will always exist once it is opened in the line above, and this change was made to avoid having to create a flag before opening and having the race condition.

content.raw: Then it should be restructured \(see my `elif` statement below\) so it’s obvious that these parameters are explicitly not copied on that final condition.
content.html: Then it should be restructured (see my elif statement below) so it’s obvious that these parameters are explicitly not copied on that final condition.

content.raw: We can avoid importing the `io` module altogether if all we need is `tell`. You could check if the file exists with `Path(filename).exists()` or even `seek` from the `os` module \(seeking 0 bytes from the current position to get the current position returned\).
content.html: We can avoid importing the io module altogether if all we need is tell. You could check if the file exists with Path(filename).exists() or even seek from the os module (seeking 0 bytes from the current position to get the current position returned).

content.raw: Will change
content.html: Will change

content.raw:
`# bulk copy options that need no further processing `

`dst = cls.options_to_attrs[option] `

`res.set_option(dst, options_dict[option])`

In this section at the bottom of the for loop, we copy all the options to Runner. These are skipped since there won’t be a corresponding runner attr or it will have already been set.
content.html:
# bulk copy options that need no further processing

dst = cls.options_to_attrs[option]

res.set_option(dst, options_dict[option])

In this section at the bottom of the for loop, we copy all the options to Runner. These are skipped since there won’t be a corresponding runner attr or it will have already been set.

content.raw: If you are using `continue` you can just use `elif` \(and `else` for the end if you wish\) instead on these multiple clauses. I think you can reorganize the code this way so it’s obvious what should be conditional and what should happen on every iteration \(if anything\).
content.html: If you are using continue you can just use elif (and else for the end if you wish) instead on these multiple clauses. I think you can reorganize the code this way so it’s obvious what should be conditional and what should happen on every iteration (if anything).

content.raw: I don’t think it’s worth checking those options just to do nothing, if you are iterating over those options, they will, by default, \(should\) be doing nothing.
content.html: I don’t think it’s worth checking those options just to do nothing, if you are iterating over those options, they will, by default, (should) be doing nothing.

content.raw: This code is not changed from before, only moved to run for both train and identify. I’d make the argument that this is alright since a ENOENT will still be thrown later when triangulation is tried and the input.master and segway.str don’t exist. If there is a better solution to this though, maybe checking traindir.isdir\(\) immediately before this?
content.html: This code is not changed from before, only moved to run for both train and identify. I’d make the argument that this is alright since a ENOENT will still be thrown later when triangulation is tried and the input.master and segway.str don’t exist. If there is a better solution to this though, maybe checking traindir.isdir() immediately before this?

content.raw: If the train directory is misspecified - then it will definitely throw an `IOError` where the error code is \`ENOENT\`. There probably needs to be some rethinking about how this error is checked.
content.html: If the train directory is misspecified - then it will definitely throw an IOError where the error code is `ENOENT`. There probably needs to be some rethinking about how this error is checked.

content.raw: This checks which attributes haven’t been set yet, and sets them all to false. Before, we set them all to false automatically but Michael had asked for it to be changed so that they’re never overwritten and all set to their correct values in this class.
content.html: This checks which attributes haven’t been set yet, and sets them all to false. Before, we set them all to false automatically but Michael had asked for it to be changed so that they’re never overwritten and all set to their correct values in this class.

content.raw:
There's a case where something like `self.identify` or `self.train` already exists at this point? Why is this check important?

Why not just, by default, have set all the `self.identify` et. al to their default, "not-running" status before or at the beginning of `set_tasks` then just set the correct tasks for running during the check on the text?
content.html:
There's a case where something like self.identify or self.train already exists at this point? Why is this check important?

Why not just, by default, have set all the self.identify et. al to their default, "not-running" status before or at the beginning of set_tasks then just set the correct tasks for running during the check on the text?
